source.title: Run PCR to Identify Positive Clones

source.description: Prepare Master PCR Mix by adding each of the below reagents to a microcentrifuge tube.

source.body: Before you start: multiply each volume below by the same amount (x 10, 15, etc.) according to how much master mix you need to run your sets.

source.title: Run PCR to Identify Positive Clones

source.description: Place PCR reaction in thermocycler and run PCR.

source.body:
Settings should be as follows:
1) 95C for 5mins (ramp up).
2) 95C for 30sec.
3) 55C for 45 sec.
4) 72C for 45 sec.
- x35 cycles steps 2-4.
5) 72 for 10mins.

source.title: Running Gel for PCR Product Verification

source.description: Prepare a gel of 2% concentration. Run gel and examine bands. Desired band length is about 200bp with the gRNA insertion.
You have successfully transformed a lentiviral vector with your gRNA sequence of interest! For confirmation, feel free to sequence your vector.

of DNA in a microcentrifuge tube next to the bunsen burner.

source.body: When working with the E. coli, be very diligent and make sure you are working in the sterile area of your bench near the bunsen burner flame.

source.description: Gently flick tube a few times with your finger to mix.

Incubate the competent cell/DNA mixture on ice for
.
Pick 10-15 colonies from each agar plate to suspend in an LB solution.

source.body: We originally selected only 4 colonies from each plate, but did not have a successful PCR. To increase chances of successfully amplifying the plasmid vector, we suggest picking 10-15 colonies.

source.description:
Place each colony in a tube with
of LB.

Place tubes into shaking incubator at
overnight.
Before you get started

source.body: Start this whole section (picking colony and suspension growth) sometime in the late afternoon (~4-5pm), so that you can run PCR for the bacterial plasmids you collect the next morning (~16 hours later). More than 24 hours of incubation can cause other non-ampicillin resistant bacteria to grow in the suspension tubes.
Set up an aseptic area for handling the bacterial colonies.
